These settings are included for experimentation and any changes made to them have the potential to cause instability, crashes, data loss or hardware failures.\n\nWe request you do not file bug reports if any of these settings have been changed from the defaults.
Change CPU governor and clock speed
Restore the processor settings on boot
Restore the I/O scheduler settings on boot
Customize the usage of memory to alter system performance
Compress memory for increased virtual capacity (requires reboot)
KSM reduces physical memory requirements and improves performance
Purging of bitmap memory assets allows the freeing of more RAM when needed (requires reboot)
Fix color banding and blur effect
Better graphics performance, but lower quality and may cause visual artifacts (requires reboot)
Please enter a new label. Enter an empty label to revert to stock label.
Display the name of the currently connected Wifi network
Pressing the volume rocker up/down will wake the device
When screen off, long-pressing the volume rockers will seek music tracks
Play sound when adjusting volume with hard keys
Prevent loud volume levels when headset is first plugged in
Listening at high volume for long periods may damage your hearing. Disable it with caution.
All brightness levels will be reset to their default settings.

How is brightness calculated? 

 The brightness curve is calculated by performing a cubic spline interpolation on a given number of control points. It's not a 'bucket-type' calculation where screen brightness will stay constant for a specific range of ambient brightness. That way, small changes in ambient brightness do not cause a large jump in screen brightness; however, it can be a little hard to predict the exact consequences of changing control points.
 To help with that, a preview of the calculated curve can be examined. Please note that the preview shows the curve in logarithmic scale, so that all control points can be shown distinctively. When using a linear scale, it wouldn't be possible to distinguish the tendentially more important control points in the lower range of ambient brightness. 

 How to edit the brightness curve? 

 Each line in the brightness list corresponds to one control point of the brightness curve. To edit the brightness level of the point, you can use the slider present in each line. The screen brightness will be changed accordingly while touching the slider to give a preview of the light level.
 Additional options are available by long-pressing a line. By selecting 'Edit', you can both edit the ambient brightness level of the control point as well as manually input the desired screen brightness. Selecting 'Split' allows you to to duplicate one line into two in order to insert additional control points. 'Remove' deletes the selected line.

, while selecting the icon will bring up customization options

To add a %1$s, select the Add icon. Once a %1$s is added, selecting the row will change the target%2$s

To remove a %1$s, swipe the row horizontally left or right. Re-order a %1$s in the list by vertically dragging the anchor on the left.

To clear or reset to defaults, select the Reset icon.
Removing every %1$s in the list will disable the feature entirely.
Change the shorcuts icon color mode
Help us make Gummy a better rom by submitting patches to review.gummyrom.com
Help make this ROM better by opting into anonymous statistics reporting

Opting into anonymous statistics will allow non-personal data to be submitted to the developers to track unique installations across devices. The information submitted includes an unique identifier, which does not compromise your privacy or personal data.\n\nFor an example of the data that is submitted, tap on Preview Data.
Whether to show icons or text on your toggles.
Choose how many toggles to show per row
Choose the order in which your toggles are displayed

Short press for Toggles, Long press for Settings
Reset all toggles and their order

Select the side that triggers the fast toggle
Delay to use after long pressing the screenshot toggle

Each click causes the toggle to move to the next action. If your toggle has an empty click action and no custom icon; the long click action\'s icon will be used.\nThis is useful for users who want their click actions to simply cycle through toggle actions without launching anything.

Useful for aligning task to displayed icon per your specific usage

The charging animation may result in a poor user experience. Enable at your own discretion.

ART is not supported by Gummy. This setting is included for experimentation only and has the potential to cause instability, crashes, data loss or prevent the proper boot of your device. Visit Introducing ART for more information.

We request you do not file bug reports if you have enabled ART as your runtime.
